Description: Letter to the Local Tribunal, Cardigan.

Transcription: Council School, Aberporth. 8th March, 1916. To the Local Tribunal, Cardigan. Gentlemen, I regret that I cannot appear before you because my health has been indifferent for the last three weeks. I have a serious objection to take life and I have been preaching that for the last ten years. I believe that international disputes could be settled without the shedding of blood. However, I am patriotic and I should like to do something short of taking life for my country. I understand that mine sweeping is dangerous and that men are wanted in that sphere. I am ready gentlemen, to undertake such work but it will create great hardship, indeed. I do not know what is to become of my invalid mother. It will mean very serious hardship to her as I have to pay a woman to nurse her, and I cannot do so if I am not exempted. I have incurred debts during ill health in college, so I am already in financial difficulties. I am preaching almost every Sunday and it is only with the remuneration I get, plus my salary that I can keep the home fires burning. Yours faithfully, T. Bryn Jones. [Stamped Cardigan R.D.C.]

Transcription: from County Education Offices, Cambrian Chambers Aberystwyth 7th March 1916 Dear Sir I understand that Mr T Bryn Jones, Headteacher of Aberporth Council school, is making an appeal to the local tribunal for exemption on personal grounds and I write to state on his behalf that it would greatly facilitate the staffing arrangements of the school in the County if the tribunal could grant him a temporary exemption for a few months. There is a great scarcity of teachers at the moment, but in a few months there will be a steady outflow, especially of women teachers from the different training colleges, who will be available for service in the schools. Yours faithfully Jenkin James

Transcription: Copy. Llandyssul 17 Feb. 1916 To the members of the Tribunal. Gentlemen, With reference to Mr E. J. Jones I may perhaps be allowed to say that I consider him as indispensable for the proper carrying on of the Postal work at Tanygroes P.O. as his mother who is the Sub-Postmistress is getting old and since her appointment many new innovations as regards Postal facilities have been introduced such as foreign parcel Pension work and army pay allowance which has made the work more intricate and is rather too much to expect Mrs Jones to perform. For many years the son has practically attended to the post office work and I shall be glad if you will grant him an exemption as you are aware the Sub Postmasters are exempted & I consider Mr Jones as the acting Sub-Postmaster of Tanygroes and would like him to have the same privilage. I am Yours Truly D.Price Postmaster

Description: Letter

Transcription: To the Chairman and members of the Cardigan Rural District Local Tribunal and to all others whom it concern. Gentlemen, I beg to submit for your consideration and approval the following as the grounds upon which I claim the renewal of his exemption for my manservant Thos Lewis Williams who is 19 years of age since the 8th of this month, single and unattested having been in the same occupation since he was 14 years of age, being a willing and industrious person kind to man and beast, total abstainer from beer and tobacco in my opinion an indispensable person in his present employment. As for myself I am farming over 140 acres of land of which 40 are arable 30 do hay and the remainder pasture, the present stock on the farm is 40 head of cattle, 64 sheep and lambs, 7 working horses and 4 young horses together with a lot of pigs and poultry. The present staff on the farm is my son (whose conditional exemption have expired on the first of this month) (the previous phrase in brackets was crossed out) and two servants, one being the man in question and a small boy of 15 years small of his age and unable to do much work with the horses except harrowing together with two daughters and a grand-daughter

Name of Tribunal: Dosbarth Gwledig Aberteifi

Number of Case: 176

Tag: Unknown document type

Description: Letter continued

Transcription: of 15 years newly left school and myself who is over 75 years of age and cannot do much work on the farm. So under the present circumstances I claim that it is in the national interest the man should continue in his present employment and in support of my contention I beg to draw your attention to the present state of agriculture in the district viz the scarcity of labour as well as the backwardness of the season. Most farmers have not half finished putting their crops in owing to the unfavourable weather of the past and present season and if many more young men from the district will be called up the farming industry will be undermined with the result that the food supply of the nation must suffer as without available labour the land cannot be tilled for the production of crops. I wish also to point to you the hardship and inconvenience as well as financial loss the farmers are put into owing to the men being called up at this time of the year, generally the agreement between the farmer and his servant is an annual agreement that is to say from November to November. So the first half year have expired and the point of issue is whether it is right for the farmer to pay the half year's salary in full to the servant on leaving or whether he is justified in deducting some amount from his salary on account of the different value of the respective half years to the farmer. Yours E Williams

Transcription: Rhoslyn, Penypark, Cardigan 11"3"18 Evan Evans Esqr. I should be very thankfull if you could arrange in order to exempt me from coming before the County Tribunal at Aberystwyth on Friday the 15th inst re. Oliver Davies. Being that my dear husband passed away on the 3rd of this month, I have no man, or boy, to carry on the work on the farm and being that my husband was bad for a long time, the ploughing etc. has been held back therefore it will be very inconvenient for me to let Oliver come, and my feelings are too much to be explained in words. I beg to state that the acreage of the farm is 16. Under the plough= 16. Horses =2, Cattle etc =12, Pigs =4. Also I beg to state that Oliver has been exempted by the "Local Tribunal" for a month in order to find work on a farm and he has agreed to work for me as my servant, and is already in my employ, he is actually ploughing at present, and as I stated above, it will be a great loss to lose one day, as the work is far behind.

Transcription: Trewen Newcastle Emlyn October 23 1918 Dear Sir I beg to write on behalf of Mr Griffith Lodwick Glynllwyd who is to appear before the appeal tribunal next Friday at Lampeter. I beg to state that he was granted conditional exemption by the appeal tribunal on 6th July 1917 by which he was to assist in farm work during four days in the week. Since then he has always been most obedient to respond to the call of the farmers of the district. His mother being a widow in advanced age is depending in him to carry on the work on her small farm. His two brothers have voluntarily joined the colours at the outbreak of war. Having now had experience in farm work he is now desirous to continue in the same. I beg also to call your attention to the fact that he is placed in Grade 3. I greatly trust that you can arrange to continue his conditional exemption on the same lines as before I remain yours faithfully D Evans Trewen
